person.note: For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.

Considered Jewish because the name included the possible Semitic בר (son) element, but see Introduction 6.6.2.1. The inscription includes the pagan formula D(is) M(anibus) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
Jewishness suggested based on brother’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.2, and under Meir (S-H/M), n. 1. IJO 2 decided not to include it in its corpus, see p. 482, n. 6.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
The papyrus is composed in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
The form Ταβιθά is recorded in under Tabitha (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 420. Perhaps the additional ι here is a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.1.

Jewishness suggested based on name, but see above, n. 1. טביא means “gazelle” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 516. Further on this name see vol. 1, p. 420. Because it is mentioned in the New Testament, some scholars consider it a Jewish name, but see Introduction 6.6.2. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 420.
The editor dated the inscription to the “Kaiserzeit.”
See Introduction 2.1. This form is recorded for Palestine, see under Mara (2) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 422.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. This form is recorded for Palestine, see under Mara (2) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 422.

person.note: In Greek – ἐτῶν π’.
See above, n. 3. Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. This form is recorded for Palestine, see under Mara (2) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 422.

person.note: In Greek – κβ’.
This entire tomb seems to have housed a tight-knit family, whose names reappear over the generations and which included Joseph (106), see Introduction 6.5.5.
This is the latest date mentioned on an inscription in the tomb. Her father is mentioned in an inscription dated to 57-8 CE.
See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated to one of these years.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.

person.note: Jewishness suggested based on the name, but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1.
See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7. On this sort of abbreviation see introduction 2.3.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. Jewishness suggested based on the name, but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1.

person.note: The papyrus is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – τῶν τριῶν Περσῶν (all three Persians).
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The papyrus is dated.
The reading is according to Clarysse, “Jews in Trikomia,” 195, see Introduction 2.1. The editio princeps had [̓Ισ]άριον, see Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2.
See above, n. 6. Jewishness suggested based on the name, but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1. The reading may well be incorrect, see previous note.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.

person.note: Jewishness is suggested by Clarysse, “Jews in Trokomia,” 199.

note.ref: See above, n. 16. See above, n. 2.

person.note: In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν εἴκοσι τρίω[ν].
On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.
The inscription is dated.

See above, n. 1, מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. WGE, 862, mentions the name Μάριον, but claims it is not Greek but rather Phoenician (see WGE862, under Μαριεύς). The form MRYWN is a recorded name for males in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37. As can be seen from this list, for women, this name is recorded only in Egypt and neighboring Cyrenaica. It is recorded in 19 instances, but of these only 5 can be identified unquestionably as Jewish. Nevertheless, for some reason it has been identified as a Jewish name, see e.g. CPJ 1, p. 187. Based on this supposition, scholars have identified all the others by this name as Jewish. However, this is a circular argument and unconvincing, see Introduction 6.6.4. and Introduction 2.7.
In Greek – ἱερισα … ὡς ἐτῶν ν’.

note.ref: See above, n. 20. On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

person.note: The inscription is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – ὡς ἐτῶν λε’.

note.ref: See above, n. 20. On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

person.note: The inscription is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
See above, n. 20. On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

person.note: The inscription is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – ὡς β’.
Jewishness was suggested on the assumption that the tombstone came from Leontopolis, but see above, n. 20. On inscriptions from Leontopolis see Introduction 6.5.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – πζ’.
Jewishness indicated by Joshua (18) mentioned on this tombstone, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7. The reversal of ι and ο is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.8.3.
In Greek – λε’.

The inscription comes from Apollonia, and may have been described by Robinson, AJA 17 (1913) 185, as follows: “In regard to the date of these inscriptions from the tombs west of Apollonia, it should be noted that in several cases the seven-branched candlestick is roughly incised at the side of the entrance,” see Introduction 6.3.1.However, he may have referred to other tombs, see Introduction 6.5.5. The editor suggested the first name on this tombstone is [̓Ιου]δίων which is obviously derived from Judah, see Introduction 6.6.8 but the remaining readable letters could be part of many other (non-Jewish) names.
The inscription is dated.
See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7. On the interchange of ο and ω see introduction 2.3.3.3.
The editor admitted there was nothing specifically Jewish in the tomb, and see Introduction 6.5.5.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – μ’.
She is buried in a cave with Joshua (22), see Introduction 6.5.5.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – ο’.
Considered by the editor Jewish because of vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.

note.ref: See above, n. 22. See above, n. 1, and Introduction 2.7.

person.note: In Greek – μ’.

note.ref: See above, n. 6. Jewishness suggested based on the name, but this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1.

person.note: The inscription is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. See Introduction 2.1. The form Marion is more common than Marin in Egypt. On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.

person.note: Jewishness suggested by the editors based on name (La femme porte un nom juif, bien attesté en Égypte), but see above, n. 1. מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. WGE, 862, mentions the name Μάριον, but claims it is not Greek but rather Phoenician (see WGE862, under Μαριεύς). The form MRYWN is a recorded name for males in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37. As can be seen from this list, for women, this name is recorded only in Egypt and neighboring Cyrenaica. It is recorded in 19 instances, but of these only 5 can be identified unquestionably as Jewish. Nevertheless, for some reason it has been identified as a Jewish name, see e.g. CPJ 1, p. 187. Based on this supposition, scholars have identified all the others by this name as Jewish. However, this is a circular argument and unconvincing, see Introduction 6.6.4.
The editor dated the inscription to the Hellenistic era.
1. The amulet is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2; and 2. the mother’s name is biblical, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
The amulet is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.
The subject of the papyrus is an annulment of a wet-nurse contract.

Jewishness suggested based on name, but this is not decisive, see above, n. 1. מרתא means “mistress” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. The name is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 695; and in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37. It has often been mistakenly identified as a Jewish name, and persons bearing it were identified as Jewish based on it, but see Introduction 6.6.2. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 423-4.
The papyrus is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.

person.note: A certain Πρωτάρχου is described in the text as Μάρθας πάτρωνος (Martha’s patron).

note.ref: See above, n. 4. Jewishness suggested based on name, but this is not decisive, see above, n. 1.

person.note: The papyrus is dated.
The editors alternatively suggest Μαρ[ί]α, see Introduction 2.1.

This papyrus is dated to the fourth century (early Christian) and is replete with biblical names. Some would interpret them as Jews (e.g. Fikhman, SCI 13 [1994] 213-4), but the editor cautiously noted “Also remarkable is the fact that this wooden board contains a certain concentration of ‘Jewish’ names … These names are probably connected with Christianization of the village of Kellis during the 4th century … as there seems no good reason to think that there was a kind of ‘Jewish quarter’ in the village or its neighborhood,” and see Introduction 6.6.7.
The additional ו is a scribal error, see introduction 2.8.1.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.2.
On such transliterations see Introduction 2.7.
Martha of this obscene graffito is probably a Semitic slave, but not necessarily Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2, and above, n. 1.
The destruction of Pompeii through the eruption of the Mount Vesuvius occurred in this year.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.

person.note: In Greek – Μιλησία.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. Jewishness suggested based on name, but this is not decisive, see above, n. 1.

person.note: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4. On the interchange of θ and τ see Introduction
Jewishness suggested based on title, γερουσιάρχου mentioned in the inscription, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.

person.note: In Greek – Λακεδαιμονία.

note.ref: See above, n. 4. Jewishness suggested based on name, but this is not decisive, see above, n. 1.

person.note: The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.

person.note: In Greek – πε’.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Martha (5) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, pp. 423-4.

person.note: See above, n. 4. Jewishness suggested based on name, but this is not decisive, see above, n. 1. No Jewish community is attested in Sicily so early, but see under Mattathias (16).
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
For this form in Palestine see under Susanna (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 426.

Jewishness indicated by name, but see above, n. 1. שושנה in the Bible is the lily, see e.g. Song 2:2, and Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4. Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel, see C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions(The Anchor Bible; New York 1977) 77-116. It is universally acknowledged as a Jewish name, and before the rise of Christianity can probably be considered as such, but not later. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 426.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Susanna (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 426.

person.note: Jewishness suggested based on name. If it is early, she is Jewish, see above, n. 1. שושנה in the Bible is the lily, see e.g. Song 2:2, and Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4. Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel, see C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions(The Anchor Bible; New York 1977) 77-116. It is universally acknowledged as a Jewish name, and before the rise of Christianity can probably be considered as such, but not later. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 426. If later, she could be Christian, see Introduction 6.6.7.
See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Susanna (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 426. For the interchange of ου and ο see Introduction 2.3.3.3. For the single ν see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Jewishness decided by the bilingual (Jewish and Greek) characters, see Introduction 6.2.3. The inscription is dated early because of the Greek see Introduction 6.5.8.
See above, n. 2. For this form in Palestine see under Susanna (1) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, p. 426. For the interchange of ου and ω see Introduction 2.3.3.3.
In Latin (in Greek letters) βικ αν μεσιβος XVIII (=18 months).

Jewishness of this inscription was suggested based on the name, see above, n. 1, שושנה in the Bible is the lily, see e.g. Song 2:2, and Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4. Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel, see C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions(The Anchor Bible; New York 1977) 77-116. It is universally acknowledged as a Jewish name, and before the rise of Christianity can probably be considered as such, but not later. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 426. but according to JIWE 1, 203, it is more likely a Christian name, see Introduction 6.5.8.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

note.ref: See above, n. 8. See above, n. 2. For the interchange of ου and ω see Introduction 2.3.3.3.

person.note: Jewishness suggested based 1. on the identification of the curse (εἴ τις ἕτερον επιβαλῖ δώσι λόγον Θεῶ – If anyone throws another [body] in he will be accountable to God) as Jewish, but see Introduction 6.10.1.3; and 2. on the name of his daughter-in-law (Susanna), but see Introduction 6.6.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 11. The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.

person.note: On this form of the name see under Shelamzion (10) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, and n. 20, pp. 427-8.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this form of the name see under Shelamzion (10) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, and n. 20, pp. 427-8.

person.note: The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. This is a list of mostly biblical names, so I consider them all Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. On this form of the name see under Shelamzion (10) (S-H/F) in vol. 1, and n. 20, pp. 427-8.

person.note: The inscription is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.4.
The document is in Jewish characters, see Introduction 6.2.1. Particularly those of a personal nature like this one, are considered Jewish.

div.note: אמא/אימא means “mother” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 50. The name is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 5. More on this name see vol. 1, pp. 418-9. In this volume, the Greek form ̓Αμμία is not recorded together with Imma, and see under Ammia (1) (G/F).
On this name see under Gadia (S-H/M), n. 1. This is a rare case where a name is both male and female, see vol. I, Introduction 1.5.2, p. 15.
חרק in Aramaic means “to cut a gap, to squeeze into a gap, to squeeze.” חרקא means “edge, notch.” The form ḤRKN is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 184.

טביא means “gazelle” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 516. Further on this name see vol. 1, p. 420. Because it is mentioned in the New Testament, some scholars consider it a Jewish name, but see Introduction 6.6.2. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 420.

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. It is recorded for males too, see vol. 1, p. 392. Stark, PNPI, 37, argues that MR’/H in Palmyra is feminine. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 422-3.

מרא means “lord, master” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. WGE, 862, mentions the name Μάριον, but claims it is not Greek but rather Phoenician (see WGE862, under Μαριεύς). The form MRYWN is a recorded name for males in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37. As can be seen from this list, for women, this name is recorded only in Egypt and neighboring Cyrenaica. It is recorded in 19 instances, but of these only 5 can be identified unquestionably as Jewish. Nevertheless, for some reason it has been identified as a Jewish name, see e.g. CPJ 1, p. 187. Based on this supposition, scholars have identified all the others by this name as Jewish. However, this is a circular argument and unconvincing, see Introduction 6.6.4.

מרתא means “mistress” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 834. The name is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 695; and in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 37. It has often been mistakenly identified as a Jewish name, and persons bearing it were identified as Jewish based on it, but see Introduction 6.6.2. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, pp. 423-4.
פלטיא means “wide street, highway (πλατεῖα)” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1179. The form FLTH is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 471.

שושנה in the Bible is the lily, see e.g. Song 2:2, and Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1543-4. Alternatively, שושן in the Bible (Esth 1:2) is the capital of the Persian Empire. Justi, INB, 318, records the Persian name “Sūsanek.” The name Σουσάννα is first recorded for the apocryphal heroine of the short story named after her and appended to the Book of Daniel, see C. A. Moore, Daniel, Esther and Jeremiah: The Additions(The Anchor Bible; New York 1977) 77-116. It is universally acknowledged as a Jewish name, and before the rise of Christianity can probably be considered as such, but not later. For this name in Jewish characters see vol. 1, p. 426.

The name שלמציון (=“the peace of Zion,” or “the wholeness of Zion”) is not biblical. It was a new and popular Jewish name for women in the Second Temple period in Palestine. It went out of use soon after, see vol. 1, pp. 426-9. From the list here we may surmise that it originated in the Jewish Egyptian Diaspora.

תם means “perfect, unblemished” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1674. The form TM is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 136. The form TM’ is recorded for women in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 56.
